    \index{pystroke \textit{(package)}!pystroke.vex \textit{(module)}!pystroke.vex.Vex \textit{(class)}|(}
\subsection{Class Vex}

    \label{pystroke:vex:Vex}
Vector sprite class (consider renaming) - consists of a list of points 
which are rendered relative to an x and y at draw time

\textbf{Author:} James Heslin (PROGRAM\_IX)




%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%
%%                                Methods                                %%
%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%

  \subsubsection{Methods}

    \label{pystroke:vex:Vex:__str__}
    \index{pystroke \textit{(package)}!pystroke.vex \textit{(module)}!pystroke.vex.Vex \textit{(class)}!pystroke.vex.Vex.\_\_str\_\_ \textit{(method)}}

    \vspace{0.5ex}

\hspace{.8\funcindent}\begin{boxedminipage}{\funcwidth}

    \raggedright \textbf{\_\_str\_\_}(\textit{self})

    \vspace{-1.5ex}

    \rule{\textwidth}{0.5\fboxrule}
\setlength{\parskip}{2ex}
    Returns a string containing the x and y of the vector sprite

\setlength{\parskip}{1ex}
      \textbf{Return Value}
    \vspace{-1ex}

      \begin{quote}
      A string containing the x and y of the vector sprite

      {\it (type=string)}

      \end{quote}

\textbf{Author:} James Heslin (PROGRAM\_IX)



    \end{boxedminipage}

    \label{pystroke:vex:Vex:__init__}
    \index{pystroke \textit{(package)}!pystroke.vex \textit{(module)}!pystroke.vex.Vex \textit{(class)}!pystroke.vex.Vex.\_\_init\_\_ \textit{(method)}}

    \vspace{0.5ex}

\hspace{.8\funcindent}\begin{boxedminipage}{\funcwidth}

    \raggedright \textbf{\_\_init\_\_}(\textit{self}, \textit{x}, \textit{y}, \textit{colour}, \textit{points}, \textit{width}, \textit{scale\_x}={\tt 1}, \textit{scale\_y}={\tt 1})

    \vspace{-1.5ex}

    \rule{\textwidth}{0.5\fboxrule}
\setlength{\parskip}{2ex}
    Constructs a new Vex

\setlength{\parskip}{1ex}
      \textbf{Parameters}
      \vspace{-1ex}

      \begin{quote}
        \begin{Ventry}{xxxxxxx}

          \item[x]

          The X (horizontal) co-ordinate of the vector sprite

            {\it (type=int)}

          \item[y]

          The Y (vertical) co-ordinate of the vector sprite

            {\it (type=int)}

          \item[colour]

          The colour of the vector sprite

            {\it (type=pygame.Color)}

          \item[points]

          The points that make up the vector sprite

            {\it (type=list/tuple of tuples (int, int))}

          \item[width]

          The width of the vector sprite's lines

            {\it (type=int)}

          \item[scale\_x]

          The horizontal multiplier of the vector sprite's size

            {\it (type=double)}

          \item[scale\_y]

          The vertical multiplier of the vector sprite's size

            {\it (type=double)}

        \end{Ventry}

      \end{quote}

\textbf{Author:} James Heslin (PROGRAM\_IX)



    \end{boxedminipage}

    \label{pystroke:vex:Vex:dir_vec}
    \index{pystroke \textit{(package)}!pystroke.vex \textit{(module)}!pystroke.vex.Vex \textit{(class)}!pystroke.vex.Vex.dir\_vec \textit{(method)}}

    \raggedright \textbf{dir\_vec}(\textit{self})

    \vspace{-1.5ex}

    \rule{\textwidth}{0.5\fboxrule}
\setlength{\parskip}{2ex}
    Return a copy of the vector sprite's direction vector (the first vector
    in its list of points), adjusted to have absolute co-ordinates

\setlength{\parskip}{1ex}
      \textbf{Return Value}
    \vspace{-1ex}

      \begin{quote}
      A copy of the vector sprites's direction vector, with absolute 
      co-ordinates

      {\it (type=Vector2)}

      \end{quote}

\textbf{Author:} James Heslin (PROGRAM\_IX)



    \end{boxedminipage}

    \label{pystroke:vex:Vex:angle_to_face_point}
    \index{pystroke \textit{(package)}!pystroke.vex \textit{(module)}!pystroke.vex.Vex \textit{(class)}!pystroke.vex.Vex.angle\_to\_face\_point \textit{(method)}}

    \vspace{0.5ex}

\hspace{.8\funcindent}\begin{boxedminipage}{\funcwidth}

    \raggedright \textbf{angle\_to\_face\_point}(\textit{self}, \textit{p})

    \vspace{-1.5ex}

    \rule{\textwidth}{0.5\fboxrule}
\setlength{\parskip}{2ex}
    Return the rotation angle (in radians) required for the vector sprite 
    to face a specified point (face: the vector sprite's direction vector 
    is pointing towards the point)

\setlength{\parskip}{1ex}
      \textbf{Parameters}
      \vspace{-1ex}

      \begin{quote}
        \begin{Ventry}{x}

          \item[p]

          The point to face

            {\it (type=Vector2)}

        \end{Ventry}

      \end{quote}

      \textbf{Return Value}
    \vspace{-1ex}

      \begin{quote}
      The rotation angle (in radians) required for the vector sprite to 
      face p

      {\it (type=double)}

      \end{quote}

\textbf{Author:} James Heslin (PROGRAM\_IX)



    \end{boxedminipage}

    \label{pystroke:vex:Vex:move_abs}
    \index{pystroke \textit{(package)}!pystroke.vex \textit{(module)}!pystroke.vex.Vex \textit{(class)}!pystroke.vex.Vex.move\_abs \textit{(method)}}

    \vspace{0.5ex}

\hspace{.8\funcindent}\begin{boxedminipage}{\funcwidth}

    \raggedright \textbf{move\_abs}(\textit{self}, \textit{x}, \textit{y}, \textit{surface})

    \vspace{-1.5ex}

    \rule{\textwidth}{0.5\fboxrule}
\setlength{\parskip}{2ex}
    Move the vector sprite in the X/Y plane without leaving the bounds of 
    the specified surface - performs vector calculation to make sure 
    diagonal movement is not faster than cardinal

\setlength{\parskip}{1ex}
      \textbf{Parameters}
      \vspace{-1ex}

      \begin{quote}
        \begin{Ventry}{xxxxxxx}

          \item[x]

          The X (horizontal) movement amount

            {\it (type=double)}

          \item[y]

          The Y (vertical) movement amount

            {\it (type=double)}

          \item[surface]

          The surface to use to restrict the movement of the vector sprite

            {\it (type=pygame.Surface)}

        \end{Ventry}

      \end{quote}

\textbf{Author:} James Heslin (PROGRAM\_IX)



    \end{boxedminipage}

    \label{pystroke:vex:Vex:move_rel}
    \index{pystroke \textit{(package)}!pystroke.vex \textit{(module)}!pystroke.vex.Vex \textit{(class)}!pystroke.vex.Vex.move\_rel \textit{(method)}}

    \vspace{0.5ex}

\hspace{.8\funcindent}\begin{boxedminipage}{\funcwidth}

    \raggedright \textbf{move\_rel}(\textit{self}, \textit{x}, \textit{y}, \textit{surface})

    \vspace{-1.5ex}

    \rule{\textwidth}{0.5\fboxrule}
\setlength{\parskip}{2ex}
    Move the vector sprite in the X/Y plane without leaving the bounds of 
    the specified surface - assumes all inputs have already been calculated
    to restrict movement speed

\setlength{\parskip}{1ex}
      \textbf{Parameters}
      \vspace{-1ex}

      \begin{quote}
        \begin{Ventry}{xxxxxxx}

          \item[x]

          The X (horizontal) movement amount

            {\it (type=double)}

          \item[y]

          The Y (vertical) movement amount

            {\it (type=double)}

          \item[surface]

          The surface to use to restrict the movement of the vector sprite

            {\it (type=pygame.Surface)}

        \end{Ventry}

      \end{quote}

\textbf{Author:} James Heslin (PROGRAM\_IX)

    \label{pystroke:vex:Vex:get_relative_points_tuple}
    \index{pystroke \textit{(package)}!pystroke.vex \textit{(module)}!pystroke.vex.Vex \textit{(class)}!pystroke.vex.Vex.get\_relative\_points\_tuple \textit{(method)}}

    \vspace{0.5ex}

\hspace{.8\funcindent}\begin{boxedminipage}{\funcwidth}

    \raggedright \textbf{get\_relative\_points\_tuple}(\textit{self})

    \vspace{-1.5ex}

    \rule{\textwidth}{0.5\fboxrule}
\setlength{\parskip}{2ex}
    Returns a list of 2D points as tuples, relative to vector sprite 
    position, respective of scale

\setlength{\parskip}{1ex}
      \textbf{Return Value}
    \vspace{-1ex}

      \begin{quote}
      A list of tuples representing the points in the vector sprite, with 
      co-ordinates relative to the vector sprite's position, respective of 
      scale

      {\it (type=list of tuples (int, int))}

      \end{quote}

\textbf{Author:} James Heslin (PROGRAM\_IX)



    \end{boxedminipage}

    \label{pystroke:vex:Vex:point_inside}
    \index{pystroke \textit{(package)}!pystroke.vex \textit{(module)}!pystroke.vex.Vex \textit{(class)}!pystroke.vex.Vex.point\_inside \textit{(method)}}

    \vspace{0.5ex}

\hspace{.8\funcindent}\begin{boxedminipage}{\funcwidth}

    \raggedright \textbf{point\_inside}(\textit{self}, \textit{v})

    \vspace{-1.5ex}

    \rule{\textwidth}{0.5\fboxrule}
\setlength{\parskip}{2ex}
    Determines roughly if a given point is inside the vector sprite, can be
    used for crude collision detection

\setlength{\parskip}{1ex}
      \textbf{Parameters}
      \vspace{-1ex}

      \begin{quote}
        \begin{Ventry}{x}

          \item[v]

          The point to check

            {\it (type=Vector2)}

        \end{Ventry}

      \end{quote}

      \textbf{Return Value}
    \vspace{-1ex}

      \begin{quote}
      True if the point is inside the vector sprite, False otherwise

      {\it (type=boolean)}

      \end{quote}

\textbf{Author:} James Heslin (PROGRAM\_IX)



    \end{boxedminipage}
